title: AB 2162
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act (Chapter 6.3) is added to the Fish and Game Code to conserve oak woodlands, enhance scenic beauty, increase property values, promote ecological balance, and provide habitat for wildlife and plant species. It also helps reduce soil erosion, sustain healthy watersheds, moderate climate change, and improve the health and welfare of California residents. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act aims to conserve oak woodlands in California to maintain habitat for wildlife species and ecological balance. The state recognizes the threat of habitat loss due to pathogens and parasites, emphasizing the need for immediate conservation efforts to preserve oak ecosystem continuity. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act aims to conserve oak woodland ecological attributes in California, provide habitat for wildlife species, ensure land use decisions are based on scientific information, and restore the state's biologically diverse natural resource for future generations. Canopy cover is defined as the area under the live branches of an oak tree, and oak removal is causing an oak tree to die or be removed by human activity. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act defines terms related to oak removal, including oak removal permit, oak removal plan, oak tree, oak woodland, and parcel. Oak removal is defined as causing an oak tree to die or be removed by human activity. Oak woodland is land with over ten percent oak canopy cover. A parcel is a single assessor's parcel of land. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act defines terms related to oak removal, including oak removal permit, oak removal plan, oak tree, oak woodland, and parcel. It specifies that a person cannot remove a valley oak tree equal to or greater than 10 inches in diameter at breast height from an oak woodland without an approved oak removal plan and permit. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act requires an oak removal plan and permit for removing valley oak trees 10 inches or larger in diameter at breast height. The director can delegate approval authority to regional managers, and the application must be prepared and signed by a registered professional forester on a form prescribed by the director. The Oak Woodlands Protection Act mandates an oak removal plan and permit for cutting valley oak trees 10 inches or larger in diameter. A registered professional forester must prepare and sign the permit application on a form specified by the director. The commission is required to establish regulations by June 30, 2016, including an application fee for processing oak removal permits. The fee collected will cover the department's costs for administering and enforcing the Act, with funds deposited into the Oak Woodlands Protection Act Fund for this purpose. An oak removal plan is required for an oak removal permit, including details like parcel use, canopy cover percentages, oak species to be removed, and habitat mitigation measures. The director's approval of the permit is subject to the California Environmental Quality Act, and certain criteria must be met for approval. The director may seek certification for the oak removal program from the Secretary of the Natural Resources Agency. The director must not approve an oak removal permit if the application or plan does not comply with regulations, findings cannot be made, more than 10% of oak canopy would be removed, trees are within 50 feet of water, information is incorrect or incomplete, applicant lacks property interest, or if the plan violates any law. The applicant may appeal the director's denial of an oak removal permit to the commission within 15 days. The commission will hear the appeal within 60 days unless a later date is agreed upon. An applicant denied a permit is entitled to a hearing before the commission, which will decide appeals de novo. A person can seek declaratory and equitable relief to stop violations of the chapter, with preliminary relief available upon showing a violation. Oak removal permits are considered construction projects. Permittees must record approved permits before starting operations. Violating the chapter can result in a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per violation. In case of a violation of the chapter, a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per violation may be imposed. The court considers various factors in determining the amount of the penalty, including the nature of the violation, ability to pay, prior history of violations, and economic benefit resulting from the violation. Every civil action under this section is brought by the Attorney General, district attorney, or city attorney in the name of the people of California. Civil penalties collected are divided with 50% going to the county treasurer and 50% to the Wildlife Conservation Board for the Oak Woodlands Conservation Fund. Section 21083.4 of the Public Resources Code is repealed. Section 21083.4 of the Public Resources Code is repealed. Counties must determine if a project may impact oak woodlands and implement mitigation measures like conservation easements or tree planting. Maintenance of planted trees must be done for seven years. To conserve oak woodlands, mitigation measures include conservation easements, tree planting, and contributing funds to the Oak Woodlands Conservation Fund. Maintenance of planted trees is required for seven years, and other mitigation measures may be developed by the county. A county may use a grant from the Oak Woodlands Conservation Act to prepare oak conservation plans or ordinances. Exemptions include projects under approved conservation plans and affordable housing in urban areas. Projects eligible for grants under the Oak Woodlands Conservation Act include affordable housing in urban areas, conversion of oak woodlands on agricultural land, and projects under specific sections of the Public Resources Code. Compliance with oak conservation measures exempts lead agencies and projects from certain divisions of the law. This section does not limit a public agency's ability to comply with environmental regulations. This section clarifies that Section 21081 can still apply to a project and does not limit a public agency's power to comply with environmental laws. No reimbursement is required for local agencies or school districts under this act, as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
